_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The owners, management, and employees of Ag Service Inc. are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  In the event of a release, we are prepared to work with the local fire department and minimize the impact of the release on the employees, local residents, and the environment of the area.
Ag Service Inc is an ag wholesale business that sells fertilizers to dealers for resale for crop production by farmers.  Anhydrous ammonia is utilized in the plant to be combined with water and phosphorus compounds for mixed grade fertilizers for crop production nutrients.
The maximum amount that can be stored at our facility is 53000 lbs or approximately 12000 gallons of anhydrous ammonia.  The maximum amount unloaded or present at our facility at any one time would be 53000 lbs of anhydrous ammonia. 
The Worst Case Release Scenario for anhydrous ammonia would be the release of the entire storage tank in a gas release over 10 minutes.  The amount released would be 53000 lbs and would result in an end point of 1.63 miles and would effect a population of 2500.  The Fertilizer Institutes degadis model was used for the end point calculations.
The Alternate Release Scenario for anhydrous ammonia would be a pipe release over 2 minutes.  The total amount released would be 11908 lbs and would result in an endpoint of .83 miles and would effect a population of 135.  The Fertilizer Institutes degadis model was used for the end point calculations.
Accident Release Prevention Program:  The facility has complied with the Kansas Department of Agricultures Anhydrous Ammonia regulations and are inspected every year.  The plant has also done its best to comply with the ANSI K-61 published by the American National Standards Institute and the standards of the Occupational Safety and Health Administrations Ammonia regulation, 29 CFR 1910.111.
The 5-year Accident History:  There has not been a reportable accident in the past 5 years.
We have implemented and have p

osted at our anhydrous plant our emergency action plan for handling of anhydrous ammonia.  These guidelines include response in case of fire, spills or leaks, and first aid.  Employees have been trained in regards to all of these emergencies.  Ag Service Inc has a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standards.  We also have provided the Hesston Fire Department and the Harvey County Emergency Planning Commission with our community right to know information as required by SARA Title III.
Safety is a top priority at our facility.  We will continue to make periodic inspections and evaluations on the safety of our anhydrous facility.
